text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with cherry folded-up also known as
a cherry galette in certain french
baking circles but you know what we're
gonna call it a cherry fold it up just
well just to annoy the French that's
really the only reason and if you're
like me and your favorite part of fruit
pies is that crispy crust that gets all
soaked with that sir pee fruity goodness
this is for you alright so this is gonna
start with a very simple pie crust I'm
gonna take some whole wheat flour that's
right I'm using whole wheat this time so
normally I'm not a huge fan of whole
wheat flour but in this it works so
perfectly
so sugar insults and then some ice-cold
butter that I've cut in small pieces all
right I'm gonna use my pastry cutter my
pastry blender to cut in the butter into
the flour which just means working that
butter into the flour until it resembles
coarse crumbs at that point I'm gonna
stir in our top-secret liquid mixture I
hope you're sitting down for this
because that's a combination of ice
water and frozen orange vodka oh yeah
vodka in the pie crust a little trick I
picked up from Alton Brown all right so
I made it well I poured it in I started
it with a fork as soon as it starts to
come together a little bit I switched to
my hands and all we want to do is get
this dough into some sort of ball or
disc all right it's gonna feel kind of
crumbly certain spots might be a little
wet certain spots might be a little dry
it's okay all right we want a nice crisp
flaky dough so don't do too much with it
at this point as long as you can get it
together into a disc like that wrap it
in plastic and we're gonna chill that
for a couple hours in the fridge all
right while our dough is chilling let's
talk about pie filling this pie believe
it or not is gonna cost me about
eighteen dollars to make because I'm
using these Luxardo maraschino cherries
so these are Italian cherries pitted
candied in this amazing cherry syrup
crazy expensive that jar $18 I'm not
kidding
so you can use any cherry pie filling
for this but if you have access to the
Luxardo give it a
try unbelievable alright a couple hours
later my pie dough has chilled
thoroughly I'm gonna roll it out to a
large round about an eighth of an inch
thick
all right don't worry too much about
what it looks like the great thing about
this technique is no matter what it
looks like before you put it in the oven
after it bakes it looks amazing so I'm
gonna slowly roll that out only using
enough flour to keep it from sticking
once I have it to the right thickness
like I said about an eighth of an inch
and that's about 13 inches wide I'd say
12 to 14 inches will give you a range
I'm gonna trim a little bit of that
rough edge just because I want to take a
pretty picture but you don't have to I'm
gonna roll that up on my rolling pin I'm
gonna unroll it on my baking sheet that
has a silicone baking mat in the middle
I'm gonna pour 3/4 of a cup of these
Luxardo maraschino cherries just
incredible and of course I'll put a link
on the blog post for where you can find
those if you want to use those but any
canned cherry pie filling will work in a
pinch and for that matter any fruit
filling that you use for a pie will work
in this all right so I'm gonna spread
the cherries out but I'm gonna leave
about 3 or 4 inches all the way around
then and here's why it's called a cherry
folded up you're simply gonna take the
crust and fold it up towards the center
like that and you're gonna make three or
four of these big folds leaving a couple
inches in the center open and that's all
there is to it it could not be easier
and when you're folding just make sure
you make nice big folds and you tuck the
last piece underneath so none of that
cherry juice can leak out the only
opening should be in that center there
so if you need to watch that part a
couple times of how I was folding that
feel free but it is a very very simple
process just three or four folds all
gathered up at the center like that and
you're good last step we're going very
old-school a lot of times we paint this
with an egg wash but I want to go really
rustic so I'm gonna paint this with some
milk and yes I got it all over I'm gonna
paint this with some milk and then I'm
gonna liberally sprinkle it and maybe
more than liberally maybe generously
sprinkle it with white sugar that's
gonna give it a really really cool
finish as you're gonna see in a couple
minutes
once that's painting with milk and
dusted with sugar it's gonna go in a
375 degree oven for about 35 to 40
minutes all right how you know it's done
the center is gonna be bubbling away and
it will be thoroughly browned all over
until it just looks well something like
that and you can see that amazing finish
that that milk and sugar gave the crust
here so beautiful we're gonna make sure
we let that cool thoroughly before
slicing and if you do you get a
beautiful clean cut like this
unbelievable the perfect perfect
proportion of cherry sir pea filling -
crispy buttery crust and our little
secret ingredient there of that frozen
orange vodka helped create that
incredibly flaky crust structure they're
just a beautiful thing and what does
this taste like imagine the most amazing
cherry pop-tart ever that's what this
tastes like
now that looks amazing but trust me it
tastes three to four times better than
it looks if you can believe that and
like I said earlier I'm the kind of pie
person that really loves the crust sort
of that crunchy edges of the crust to
have the sugary fruit syrup kind of
stuck to it this is like an entire pie
of that so really super simple freeform
pie whatever you want to call it's fine
with me a cherry folded up a chair eagle
at whatever I just hope you give it a
try head over to food wishes comm for
all the ingredient amounts especially
for that top secret
vodka pie crust and as always enjoy
